FacilityName: E.H. Huestess Waste Water Treatment Plant

_prev_prog_3.EquipmentTested: pressure guages and all chlorine lines
_prev_prog_3.Description: The City of Cayce Waste Water Treatment Plant has a thorough description of all elements of its Prevention Program relating to the storage of a maximum of 6,000 pounds of chlorine contained in three one-ton cylinders in its Process Satety Management Plan (PSMP) as required by OSHA.  This document is held at the plant and at Cayce City Hall and Public Safety.  The elements detailed in the PSMP and outlined here include a process hazard analysis which catagorizes the likelihood of a release and any corrective measures which may need to be taken, operating procedures as described in the Operation & Maintenance manual held at the plant, training procedures which are conducted at the time of hiring of a new employee and weekly on various subjects related to plant operations and procedures, maintenance procedures which take place daily, alarm systems, containment enclosures and diking which surrounds the entire facility.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
The E. H. Huestess Waste Water Treatment Plant is committed to safety and the implementation of safe procedures through various training, safety, emergency and accidental release prevention programs, and overall process safety management.  The City is responsible for the training of all employees at the waste water treatment plant.  All new employees are provided training in the following topics, at a minimum:  the requirements of Hazard Communication Standard 29 CFR 1910.1200, chemicals used in the plant, how to read and get information from MSDS's, process hazards, use of personal protective equipment, emergency procedures, understanding process safety management, and the location of MSDS's, PSMP, and other safety information.  In addition to initial training, employees are trained on various topics related to the facility and its processes once every two weeks.
     The E.H. Huestess Waste Water Treatment Plant (WWTP) is located in southeast Cayce, adjacent to the Congaree River.  The plant currently has a daily process capacity of 9.5 million gallons per day.  The following processes provide both primary and secondary treatment and disinfection:  bar screens and grit removal system, activated sludge, disinfection using chlorine, dechlorination using sulfur dioxide, pH adjustment using sodium hydroxide if needed at the headworks, and at Pump Station #1 about 3/4's of a mile upstream of the wastewater treatment plant also located adjacent to the Congaree river, the use of Magnesium Hydroxide. Aerobic sludge digestion, and sludge thickening using belt press and drying beds.  The following substances are used in the treatment processes: chlorine,sulfur dioxide,sodium hydroxide,Magnesium Hydroxide,Clarifloc SE506 Polymer,Hydrated Lime.    
        
     The WWTP currently holds a complete Process Safety Management Plan as required by 29 CFR 1910.119,  a Stormwater Pollution Prevention Plan as required under NPDES Permit No. SC0024147, and an Operations and Maint

enance manual which outline various procedures involving, training, maintenance, inspections,  process safety, process chemical safety information, accident prevention and emergency response procedures.  
     Over the past 5-year period, no accidents have occurred involving the release of any chemicals held above a threshold quantity as defined by 29 CFR 68.130.  
     The WWTP has within its PSM Plan a detailed Emergency Planning and Response Plan outlining  coordination with local responders and individual response roles and responsibilities including names, titles and phone numbers.  Personnel safety measures and emergency health care responsibilities are also outlined in this plan.  Training which includes drills for practice in the event of an emergency release is provided at the time a new employee is hired and is also provided in refresher training courses which are provided at least every three years to current employees.  Additional safety training is provided every week on a variety of topics related to processes specific to the plant.
